Award.AwardTitle: Student Participation Support for 2018 Advanced Accelerator Concepts Workshop
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Advanced Accelerator Concepts (AAC) Workshop is a biannual topical meeting under the auspices of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. The AAC series of workshops is a major forum for the U.S. accelerator physics, engineering and technology community for the exchange and promulgation of the most advanced new ideas and concepts over the widest areas of application. An important part of maintaining this long term mission is the strong participation of students in the Workshop, where they become a part of the larger community of experts working for the continued evolution of new and unique accelerator physics concepts and technologies.

This award will enable student participation for approximately 25 US PhD students to attend and present the results of their work at the 18th Advanced Accelerator Concepts Workshop in Breckenridge, Colorado from August 12 thru August 17, 2018. This meeting is expected to attract more than 300 accelerator scientists and engineers. The Workshop will also include an event to promote diversity. This will be a Career Development Social that will feature a special guest, Dr. Patricia Rankin, a Professor at the University of Colorado, Boulder, and the current Chair of the APS Committee on Women in Physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the grant was to support student participation in the 2018 Advanced Accelerator Concepts (AAC) workshop in two ways: via reduced or waived registration fees, and subsidies for U.S. student accommodations. Students interested in obtaining participation grants were required to submit a brief application, including a description of their research and planned presentation at AAC, along with a recommendation from their research advisor. Applications were evaluated by one of the Working Group leaders for each student?s anticipated working group. The workshop Chairs selected the highest-rated applications for each Working Group, respecting topical and institutional diversity. The NSF funding paid for the registration fees ($350 each) and the accommodation costs ($358 each) of 24 students, totaling $16,999.20. Approximately one third of the students who received funding were female.

The AAC Workshop is a unique venue for advancing accelerator science in fundamental and revolutionary ways. We are not aware of any other venue with a similar collegial, student-friendly, flexible format. The workshop has a long and successful history, including in the development of students, who often go on to become productive members of the accelerator community. We consider all efforts to subsidize?and thereby encourage?student participation to be of the utmost importance, as a significant student presence is considered key to the success of the workshop.

To improve diversity, the 2018 AAC Organizing and Program committees made a deliberate effort to improve the representation of women in the high-profile roles at the Workshop, namely those of Working Group leaders and plenary speakers. In previous Workshops, there had never been more than one woman serving as Working Group leader or co-leader. This year, 6 of the 16 Working Group leaders selected by the Organizing Committee were women. There were no women giving plenary presentations at either AAC 2014 or 2016. In 2018, 6 of the 21 (29%) plenary speakers were women. Diversity was also considered in selecting chairs of the plenary sessions. To help future AAC organizers continue to improve diversity, we collected voluntary demographic information with registration. 

We also held an event at the Workshop to promote diversity. This was a Career Development Social, held on Wednesday evening. It featured a special guest, Dr. Patricia Rankin, a Professor at the University of Colorado, Boulder, and the current Chair of the APS Committee on Women in Physics.
